5QwKssyR8ERFtRA4PTtvTg.text: So I went to this place without knowing they were trying to hype British food. That's probably good, because I don't really have any interest in British food, so I wouldn't have gone if I had known. That said, I had a bubble and squeak which was delicious and was a proper British solution for a nasty British hangover.

iRmLFgSt8TOyppaBDU54kA.text: Perhaps not the cheapest option in this area but I was quite pleased with the food, especially the devilled kidneys and the veg was fresh and nicely made. Altogether this is a good place for some solid British grub.

isntfYUlTp3AzYyjUkHpMg.text: Canteen is a minimally designed restaurant that serves decent British food. I love the look of the place and would like my home to be as sleek and refined as Canteen. I have had the roast, steak, and fish and chips. All were quite good but the roast stood above the rest. It was what I think a British roast should be, simple, tasty, and hearty. They have a nice wine list and desserts are all decadent and a must. This is a great place to rest and refresh when spending a nice weekend day in Spitalfields and near by Brick Lane.

rZUqBLNZ8rpM8S8p7R802w.text: The food is fresh and good quality British food, but portions are disappointingly small so I always feel hungry afterwards. They have nice cabbage (in a traditional kind of way) and fantastic treacle tart. As a vegetarian the choices are pretty limited.

O9caevt6G_bAbd_cqiz6eQ.text: Thought i'd try this place after reading reviews. I had the Full English Breakfast and was not at all impressed. Where was it? What they served was very greasy, almost cold, and a pitiful portion. Absolutely tiny. There are many better and much cheaper cafes nearby where one can get a proper Full English Breakfast. S&M across the road on Brushfield Street is much better and there are other cafes on Middlesex Street and Wentworth Street that offer better food with much cheaper prices. My friend had the macaroni cheese and chiops and was disappointed with both the quantity and tase. He won't go back there again either. We were also served by numerous different people so it wasn't clear who we should tip. One person seated us, another took our order, another brought our food and another brought our bill. A strange place where you will leave hungry after their very greasy Full English and the macaroni cheese will leave a bad taste in your mouth.

NEvp_sr1zY5uXX8hToTMnw.text: Part of the newly refurbished Spitalfields market, this is a reliable restaurant serving a broad range of dishes. The layout is minimalist and similar to that of Wagamamas - long tables and benches and a open kitchen. I really like the roast dinners they do, and the chocolate cake dessert is delicious too!

OIHh1Z9W-r3KzJ5sCl2b0g.text: This place is billed as 'informal' but in comparison with the other eateries nearby it is, it's probably the most formal place to have lunch. The menu looks good, but you could probably get the same traditional food (sausage & mash, shepherds pie, apple crumble and custard) at one of the local café's in East London for a fraction of the price. However, if you don't mind spending the money and want a more upmarket experience, Canteen is ideal. The one thing I do rate is their fresh fruit juices, I had a pink lady apple fruit juice which was absolutely delicious. They also offer an express lunch menu, which is perfect if you're on a time-restrained lunch break.

zr7ROYo_X94UzHUbwhU4Pg.text: I actually went here based on reviews on Yelp! I thought I'd see if the average 3 star rating was true. The first thing about Canteen is its great location. It's right in the heart of Spittlefields market so it certainly has a buzz.  Me and my friends all ordered the Sunday lunch and true to its Yelp rating it proved to be average. Lovely roast potatoes, nice yorkshire pudding, not enough meat but what I had was nice, and decent vegetables. You won't be disappointed by the roast dinner, it's just not amazing. Would I go again? Maybe, but there are so many great places to eat in Spittlefields so I'd be keen to explore them first next time.

wuOWnMuW0I8mlh6rDZQ6uw.text: I love pie, mash potato and other tradionally english food this place serves...all in a very nice setting...I opted for a roast chicken salad the last time I visited- and was excellent- even when sat next to friends scoffing away on the more calorific dishes! Go visit everyone! YUM!

TQd-0P5pEWjjnALIvxj6Bg.text: I'm a big fan of Canteen's on Baker Street, so when a business acquaintance offered to meet me for lunch at Spitalfield's, it stuck out as a decent option among a million chain restaurants in the market.  While the menu is the same - full of wholesome British pub food designed with fresh ingredients - I'm sad to report that the service is not.  If you want to get out in under 90 minutes, I suggest that you be prepared to order drinks, food and pay your bill the first time the waitress approaches your table.  They are clearly understaffed which makes it challenging lunch hour for everyone involved.  That said, my roast chicken salad was great, and my guests finished every last bite of the daily pie (pork with pear and mustard) and stew (chicken with chorizo).  Maybe it's best to go at an off-peak time of day.

emM_UE5sU0elFd-8GxA4fQ.text: I always feel that this place should be more likable than it actually is: there are lots of good things about it, but it never quite seems to come together. Some of the food is excellent (I really enjoy the devilled kidneys), some rather more ordinary. There are odd decisions: I once had a roast here, served in a bowl which didn't really work. Prices are on the high side, with some dishes definitely overpriced. Again, the service has varied from really helpful to pretty neglectful. It's usually fine, but sometimes lacks warmth. The surroundings match the name - canteen-like - a look which thankfully seems to be going out of fashion as it makes only limited concessions to customer comfort. All in all, this is a place where you can get an excellent meal and will usually get a decent one. However, it's just not somewhere I've ever been able to take to my heart.

b0CViBwEPYEj1P_BfC7j-A.text: I know it's unfair for an American to criticize British food, but let's be real here.  It is not all that good or creative.  I love my meat and potatoes, but I did not visit London for its cuisine.  I understand that it has come a long way and is becoming a culinary destination, but I don't think it's quite there yet.I went to Canteen at Spitalfields with my friend who lives in London.  I did want to try out as much food as possible.  We shared an Eggs Benedict which was quite tasty.  For my main I had the standard sausages and mash.  I did find it weird that I had to order a side dish of mushy peas.  Isn't it standard to have mushy peas alongside sausages and mash?  The service was slow, but courteous.  I really shouldn't judge because I do live in New York and anywhere else the pace is slower.If I'm in London, I would come again to try out different dishes.  I did like the clean modern feel of this place.

yQ8VW8HZMPUg5nAh8gD-6w.text: New Years Day myself & 3 friends chose Canteen for late lunch and arrived to find the place was full inside, but the friendly & attentive staff invited us to wait as a table was paying and ready to leave, so we chose to stay.  We were shown to our table and the waiter took our order, an hour later our order arrived !!  To mark the special day I ordered Grapefruit Champagne to drink, at £7 a glass I was surprised the Champage arrived quite warm, however it still hit the spot after a heavy NYE !!  When the food finally arrived I found mine was very dry, friends were equally unimpressed with their choices. I was personally surprised by the less than enjoyable standard of food as the surroundings are quite impressive, clean & stylish and the waiters were good at keeping us informed  to which we smiled sweetly while slowly wasting away. We were lucky to be given a booth by the window, with nice comfy cushions to ease our wait, however I didn't envy the diners in the middle section of the room who sat on chairs with no backs and looked quite uncomfortable, I also don't relish sharing a dining table with strangers which the middle section would have been open to.Canteen do have an information booklet which I perused at leisure - the information contained within deserved 5 Stars as I learnt they only purchase their meats from farms where the animals have lived a happier life outdoors. Eggs are free range - the word Organic came up a lot, this is important to me and I hope these claims are true. Visually Canteen makes you feel you're on to a winner, the busy staff are reassuring therfore it comes as a disappointment when the eventual service & food standard falls below expectations. I wouldn't return or recommend to friends following my one & only experience which wasn't value for money.

0hvTkG6NngFfWq-q5teqZQ.text: I adore Canteen, mostly because they do a fantastic eggs benedict which you can order at any time of day. Their roasts are consistent, service is absolutely fine and it's a great spot to watch Spitalfields pass you by. Dishes I recommend would be the aforementioned eggs benny, pie of the day, chicken and chips and the macaroni cheese. Try and leave some room for pudding too, since they're all excellent, especially the cutesy little chocolate sundae.

DSPsYJVEmU3B4KUUhe6pYg.text: Spitafields market is a fantastic spot for both shopping and eating and if you pre book a table at Canteen you can experience one of London's most famous British eateries whilst watching the hustle and bustle of market life from the best seat in the house through their floor-to-ceiling windows. Canteen is like a big glass cube on the corner that you can't miss. It has a very minimalist interior, with large wood block tables, soft spot lighting and plain white crockery. Here they let their take on modern British food with a twist do the talking. It's similar to a very well mannered old British Granny who has a penchant for blue rinses and wearing purple shoes. In other words, the food here is very British, but it likes to push the boundaries ever so slightly. They serve five different types of roast dinner and I've tried the roast beef that was really something to rave about. As they emphasize on using fresh, local produce you really can taste the earthy charm of British veg that has a much more rustic and subtle flavoursome quality about it after struggling to grow after months of bad weather. The last time I went I had baked beans amongst other things and I have no idea what they do to them, but they were absolutely scrumptious. Whoever knew that beans could taste so great. They also have a great wine list that really compliments the menu, with the house wine being a good value purchase for taste/cost.Compared to the homebody soul-food loving crowd that frequent another of my favourites, Leon that's also in the market, Canteen draws in a much sassier crowd of city workers and cool kids on the block, so expect a much more upmarket affair.

Tj-bZiKqTjsiT4F04MJjAA.text: Location, location, location!  It can make or break a restaurant, I'd say.  And in this case perhaps it does both.  You can choose to either sit inside or "outside."  With outside being under the huge, airy roof of Spitalfield's Market.  I find the outside, a bit noisy and drafty, and the inside feels like I'm in a fishbowl.  But this food court-like location also is at the same time rather convenient.  If you find yourself around Spitalfield's or Liverpool Street Station and can't bare the thought of another meal at Pizza Express, then this is a dependable option.  Plus, every time I've been here the food and service has been wonderful.  The eggs florentine for brunch is amazing.  A day at Spitalfield's Market for me always starts with brunch here.

YFLaxKBA2L_x-CLPMSXvmw.text: Canteen is incredible. It's definitely my favourite place to go in the Spitalfields market area. It's good food in an intimate setting at a reasonable price for the quality. The layout was not something that I would normally go for when I was taking my girlfriend out for a meal on a Sunday night, as they have long tables where you sit by other people in fairly close proximity, but it just works really well. Everything is clean, crisp, and feels classy without being intimating or alienating. The food is fairly traditional English cuisine - steak, bangers and mash, lamb, that sort of thing - but is immaculately presented and tastes amazing. The service was great, everyone was friendly and smiling, and the lighting in there was perfect for evening dining - as in, you're not being blinded, but you can still see the person that you came in with. Absolutely no complaints. I would definitely recommend this to someone who was looking to take a date out in this area.

8HM9bMQSQGUZlDVAzy4djA.text: I have two words for this place: Pork Belly. This place serves some of the best around. Just be careful - once you have been once you'll end up going again and again, take it from me - I've almost turned into a piggy!

-M7vthnH2ELgPG1uIZY8iQ.text: For what it is Canteen was pretty good. I'd guess that its a reasonably reliable spot for traditional British cuisine in a contemporary environment.  One item I really enjoyed was the Scotch Egg.  Though the chip are not thick they are still pretty good.

YF01p1WLP2rf-DZ5e5nycg.text: I was really upset when they decided to redevelop most of Spitalfields market and turn it into a modernised glass-plated chain-ridden shopping centre but I think this branch of Canteen is probably the highlight of the changes. Reasonably priced good old-fashioned British food is the deal here. It's mostly pretty good, the Welsh Rarebit is massive, delicious and cost under five pounds, the service was friendly and efficient, the restaurant is nicely decorated. However, in these somewhat sterile surroundings, it's hard to shake off the ghost of the wonderful, packed Victorian market that used to exist here.

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom

qs6RbwB4ggkKiOjEUK1Yjw.text: There's no denying that Canteen is very stylish- the sleek minimalist decor looks more like a Japanese restaurant than a British eaterie. I had heard many great things about Canteen so I was slightly disappointed when I went. The roast was OK but I have tasted better in my local gastropub and the  price definately did not reflect the quality of food. Fortunately my food arrived on time but my friends waited an extra 10 minutes even though we ordered at the same time. The location is great and it is the perfect pace to recharge your batteries after wandering around Spitalfields Market. I would not go out of my way to eat at Canteen but if I was in the area I would consider it.  I have been told that the breakfast is amazing so I guess that's a good enough reason to return whenever I'm in Spitalfields.

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom

io3SIOLSdJPsAYxQ7YTYZQ.text: Canteen is gorgeous, sleek and serves great food. Always busy, it serves a great range of British good and all-day breakfasts (great when you've had a late night!) It boasts huge tables, great for meeting friends, and has cheerful and efficient staff. However, it's the location that bothers me: situated in the centre of Spitalfields Market, it seems kind of...sterile. I know to some the location is probably a selling point, but not to me. It seems slightly too up-scale for a market place. But that's my only gripe. Other than that, it's a cool, funky place serving decent, quality food.

M8m6hhpJwYjcBO7lCTVeEQ.text: Canteen is one of the newer eating establishments in the refurbished Spitalfields Market complex. It bills itself as simple British food done well. The tables (some are benches for 6), backless chairs, and semi-open kitchen are meant to emulate - in a very modern way - the school cafeteria look and feel, I guess. I don't care much about that sort of thing, but it's not overbearing at Canteen so it doesn't matter one way or the other too much. The vibe is very relaxed, especially if you're sitting outside (still covered by the Spitalfields roof, though) as we did. The menu, I like. It's large and covers all the bases. You can get breakfast all day long, whether you're looking for Greek yoghurt with honey and almonds, or eggs benedict, a bacon sandwich, or just toast and marmite. Lots of choice of good-sounding starters, but I had the slow-roasted pork belly with apples (very good, and done with fennel). There's also sausage and mash, chicken and chips, macaroni cheese and more: the canteen theme remains, but it's all done to a high standard. The cost, while certainly higher than canteen food, isn't bad for this part of London: £9-£12 for mains, but my pork was substantial. There are some regular dishes they serve every day, although the details change. They always have a full roast dinner (either beef, lamb, pork, or duck), they always have two stews or bakes (one meat and one veg), they always have two pies (one meat, one veg), and they always have one or two fish specials. My wife had the pollock grilled with butter and herbs and said it was excellent. We didn't go for dessert although both the chocolate and beetroot cake, and the substantial cheese board, beckoned. Wine list was decent and everything on it appeared to be available by bottle, carafe, and glass (a nice change to the places that give you little choice if all you want is a single glass). Dinner last night - pork for me, fish for her, a side of salad for me, steamed seasonal greens for her, a glass of wine each, and a bottle of sparkling water came to just under £44, with service charge included. We were full, and didn't need starter or dessert. Service was efficient and very friendly. The women at the table next to us, out-of-towners, asked the waiter if he knew how to get to Angel station. The waiter popped out his phone and happily looked up the route for them. There's another branch in the Royal Festival Hall.

8Kfgj-OVEYYvHKbTk5dnOQ.text: At first I liked Canteen (Both this one and the Southbank restaurant). I won't go into the food on offer as others have described it fine here. However it is totally overpriced. Good honest food with good fresh ingredients should be the norm (as it often is in places such as Melbourne, Australia) but is NOT in the UK. As such Canteen is one of so many London establishments that charges a premium for something that should be a given. In short Canteen sums up London for food in many ways - expensive and mediocreand a shame!

PAKxaKXpxoVX7Nt1J_LB5A.text: Had lunch here on a Sunday. The food was okay, but our seating was terrible. No booths were available, so we were at the tables in the middle. The chairs have ridiculously low backs, so it's basically like sitting on a stool. Very uncomfortable.Oh, the service was pretty bad too, but who could notice when you're busy wishing you had a chair.

7Upys467W-xzGVzFElUhxQ.text: I recently visited Canteen with some work colleagues as part of a retirement party. When first presented with the menu, back in my office, I was somewhat disdainful; I enjoy traditional British food, but the menu just screamed, well, 'school canteen' at me. Canteen prides itself on serving up traditional British food, made from freshly source ingredients. Typically, the menu boasts a variety of pies, roasts and other delights such as devilled kidneys and macoroni cheese. Upon entering Canteen, I was pleasantly surprised by the decor - light, airy and stylish, with an outside seating area for the braver-hearted soles amongst us. The waiting staff were smart and knowledgable about the food, happy to share their knowledge and answer any questions. Service was reasonably quick and friendly. I plumped for devilled kidneys to begin with, which shortly arrived. They were presented on a thick slice of white toast, seasoned with mustard which certainly tingled the tastebuds, quite a stark contrast to the crumbly sensation of the kidneys. I chose to follow this up with one of the Canteen pies - a pork and cider creation. The meat was tender, nicely complemented by the cider, though the pastry was slightly stodgy. However, my starter was heavy so the two dishes did not complement each other well - my fault for choosing heavy dishes. The mashed potato which accompanied the pie was perfect - rich and buttery, with no lumps. My colleagues were also satisfied with their choices of food - the smoke haddock being a very popular choice. Despite being full, I am a lady who cannot say no to a sweet course. After being unable to choose from the puddings on offer, my curiousity got the better of me and despite disliking beetroot, I opted for the homemade chocolate and beetroot cake having being assured by our friendly waitress that it was divine. It was certainly different and after the initial shock of chocolate and beetroot being served together, it was actually a rather pleasurable experience, with the bitterness of the chocolate cancelled out by the sweetness of the beetroot. The espresso coffee served afterwards seemed to be little more than a shot of rather weak Americano, almost as if they brewed a mug and then shared it out between the group. No side chocolate here, just a mint imperial, of the type you can buy from the local newsagents. Perhaps I ask too much, but when I pay for an otherwise excellent meal, I expect it to be excellent all the way to the end. Other than the slightly lucklustre ending, I would recommend Canteen as a relaxed dining experience at reasonable prices. You won't get exquisite, exotic delights, but you will get good, honest British food.

3tuZJzlyEtsPFb6kw-esSQ.text: A great little restaurant in Spitalfields market area. It's quite unassuming from the outside and the name of the place isn't too great, but nevertheless the staff were really friendly and attentive and the food very good. We went for an early lunch,  so I ordered macaroni cheese with tomatoes and bacon-it was delicious. Sadly my phone decided not to play ball, so no photos of that;(My friends orders scones with jam.-The jam apparently is home made on site, which is quite rare these days. my other friend order fish fingers - which were real fish goujons, not the processed stuff you might expect.The only downside was the waitress trying to charge me £50 instead of £15-always check before putting in your PIN!

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom. Specials!

n4Zj6QFKsfNsJmnENMcdYg.text: Walking around the neighborhood of the hotel we found this place to have breakfast. We went early on a Sunday morning and were quickly seated. My husband opted for the traditional english breakfast and he really enjoyed it. I went for the Eggs Royale and like my food.

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom

N3eWFRLZNq5b0KKvX9ru3A.text: Perhaps not the most imaginative choice, but Canteen has become a bit of a tradition for a mid-week dinner catch up with a friend.  Less fast-food-y than some of the other chains in Spitalfields Market, Canteen offers attractive set menus for early diners - without rushing.Last night's visit was a bit of a disappointment, though, with my first choice of wine out of stock - and my chosen desert not available either.  Seasonal icecream turned out to be vanilla ....

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom

g3SzZiZok-AMXfpGfSpkLQ.text: Went here on a weekday with a work group for a goodbye brunch for our interns. There were plenty of tables and I liked the simple, minimalist look of the place which gave it quite a trendy feel.I got the impression that the waiters don't bring over more menus other than the one or two on the table which I thought was odd, so with 7 of us in the group we had to ask for more.However, when my eggs royale turned up I wasn't bothered as it was delicious, the eggs were cooked to perfection which is key. If you add a drink to the mix then I'd say it is a little pricey but the the jugs of water that are brought to the table as standard is a nice touch.

7ODPCL5TZLLcsj39YZ4y-Q.text: This may be a chain but it is a good chain -and a reliable bet for good British food.They have the full line of "normal British stuff" not all of which we have had.I give particular kudos for -a) the onger steak.cheap steaks are very hard to pull off.(most french steak frites are inedible and i have had as many wretched cheap steaks in britain and in latin america as i can stand) .Canteen does a first rate "cheap steak". It has an excellent char on the outside - and red and tasty on the inside and is tender.(You usually get tasty OR tender but not both - and you rarely see chars except on shoe leather.)b) the carrots and swede (always a balancing act to keep the swede taste but not have the mash taste so strong as to be overwhelming)c) totally decent breakfastsd) totally decent coffeee) fish and chips that are absolutely first rate. a very delicate tempura like crust on a huge serving of fish of the day.(but then there is a lot of good fish and chips in upscale british places)other people have complained about service here - but the service we received was excellent.overall a strong place.

8disgNE4VRlxm5Y6Ki5WJg.text: Had lunch here today with a colleague, we were both after some comfort food after a late night.We both ordered fish and chips, which was Haddock, and an Artichoke salad. Everything was fine but a little bland, perhaps under seasoned?For desert we both choose apple crumble and custard, which was disappointing. The crumble had been microwaved, some of the apple was volcanically hot. The Custard tasted of nothing, very oddLunch was something of a let down.Lu

_J7n7OIjR6ZbHsdqWVmHag.text: Good service and food.  Eggs benedict were good .. Fish fingers great!  Nice not to have to que up to get in on a busy Sunday morning

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom. Eggs benedict
Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom. Real pieces of fish fingers! :)

gL87MnCGiYaFvdqmqjALlA.text: I like pie.Canteen have award winning pies, so when it was suggested as a lunch venue I was very happy!I should point out that they have other things on the menu, but as most of us ordered pie I'm focussing on that (I believe the fish dish was very tasty).Pie of the day was chicken and mushroom, I ordered mine with mash rather than chips because MASH. We ordered drinks and some cheese straws to tide us over. The beer choice is pretty good, Bitter & Twisted for me, which worked well with the very cheesy, flaky cheese straws which were nice but a little bit on the dry side.And then it was time for pie!The pies are individually baked and of a good size, not too much that you end up feeling stuffed and, unlike other places, they were actually pies, not the 'stuff in a bowl with pastry on top' abominations other places dare to call a pie!!I was a little disappointed by the portion of mash, but that's probably just because my love of the potato is so high. The mash was good, thick, not too creamy and well seasoned. The accompanying cabbage and gravy were ok too, a nice crunch to the cabbage and the gravy was well flavoured.The pie itself was tasty, but for the much touted 'award winning' mention I had expected better. It wasn't bad, the crust was flaky, the filling tasty but it was just a pretty good pie, not sure it was worthy of an award. The main reason we were there was to meet up with some friends so, from that point of view it was an excellent lunch! (I'm lucky that I am friends with some very lovely people). Service wise we were well attended, and overall it was a good meal.3 stars feels a little harsh but to give 4 I'd need to have been more impressed than I was. It's a nice space, with competent friendly staff and good food, but it's nothing particularly special.

lTbLbD1R5d66NCh21Xehqg.text: I have to admit, i'm not a huge fan of British food. I only like British food when its  home made. Like a good roast made at home. you get the picture. But my mates wanted to come here, so we did. And given that your in the new overpriced crappy trendy area like Spitalfields, your pretty much guaranteed this chained restaurant is going to be crap. But I kept my gob shut, sometimes I can be an over bearing mouthy twat, who is often wrong. he heThis time I wasn't. It really was crap! My friends got the breakfasts and couldn't believe that you get a typical fry up but half the size of a normal one and quadrupal the price. Everyone's chips were also burnt, i have to admit, i did like that. But I know its a mistake and they should have made new ones. So for 5 people, our total bill was 120. Hmmm, it was just pub grub!!! Not a fan of this place, but i'm also not a fan of pub grub so it comes off as a bad start for me anyways

NNizfc5igBcnWeO3zIXJjQ.text: Looking for high quality British Foods, then go to the Canteen! We enjoyed every dish! After a day of shopping at Spittafields Market, we had a great lunch here. Try the farm raised orange eggs! Amazing! The menu offers a great selection of delicious British foods and desserts. The waitress was very kind and provided great customer service.

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom. Delicious bread pudding!
Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom. Devilled Kidneys!
Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom. Smoked mackerel!

7fnZv3LePjC08LXQu5zOvg.text: It has its location going for it, in the heart of Spitalfields - which makes it super convenient - but not a whole lot else. It's quite expensive for what you get I find, although it is usually decent fare. I like their pies here - but some of the other menu items can be a little hit and miss. I've not had the roast here - I'm told its very good indeed.

voi4lYij5npA9D_L-yGBpA.text: Food was very average. Had a Sunday roast (beef) and at £15 I was expecting something decent but was left disappointed. Portion size was reasonable with a massive and tasty Yorkshire pudding but that is where the positives end. The beef was stringy and chewy and the potatoes were like bullets which is normally an indication of reheating. Service was friendly but not enough to convince me to return.

b-nzhJeprtHO_uF2PsRT8Q.text: It was the first time either of us had been to Canteen. My girlfriend had booked online from Austria and I'd travelled down from Manchester. When we first looked in the door it was empty. It looked like a small cafe and at first we thought we had the wrong place. So we walked around the block. When we returned having found no alternative we walked in. We then saw one staff member who led us to the interior which was a bit like the Tardis. It's not immediately obvious from the front door but the restaurant is quite extensive and expands out as you walk toward the rear of the smaller first bit of the building. The staff were friendly and the food was great. Having power points under the table was a nice touch. The wifi was also good. It's surprising how many places get the wifi wrong. I think their wifi password was bangersandmash from memory. I appreciated the comedy value. The scones were divine as were the sandwiches. They were so good in fact we asked for the recipe and they obliged. They only lost a star because when we asked for another pot of tea the waiter forgot and after 15 minutes of waiting we had to prompt another member of staff. I liked the vibe in Canteen. It was unhurried and had a retro cafe feel to it without the negative aspects of a greasy spoon. Not dissimilar to the Ace Cafe.

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom
Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom
Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom

X465I3JYE8fkyOapYN38Jw.text: Good British food and friendly service. A nice place to stop for a bite to eat while shopping at Spitalfields on Sunday, although it's better to come on the early side as it can get a bit of a queue. I enjoyed the soup of the day with soda bread. The side leaf salad was particularly tasty.

SlJ4mGa4PP0ao_4OYf5BHQ.text: Canteen was one of my usual haunts when I would be in London for business several times a year.  They feature an updated menu of British food, all high quality and quite good, with several vegetarian options.  The decor is modern and fun, and the atmosphere is lively without being too overwhelming.

-smikb19rxJ1c6W-0lKI0g.text: With all the hype surrounding Canteen's crusade to promote proper British grub I think I built my expectations a bit too high. Although the food was nice, I wouldn't say it was award winning. My macaroni cheese was tasty enough and my boyfriend enjoyed his chicken and chips but I'm not sure either meal merited their price tag. I'm not a big fan of the minimalist look they've gone for with the decor either. When you're served a mountain of mac and cheese you really need to recline in a proper chair afterwards and work up the energy to walk it off. Long tables and bright lights make it feel like the worst sort of canteen, one you might find in a hospital ward or a run down school. Our service was a bit patchy and although the waiter was very pleasant, he got our drinks order wrong twice and then brought us the wrong bill!I realise that this review sounds a bit negative but it's based on the principal that whilst this is a good place to eat, it's not the best. If you've read as much about this place as I had then you might have heightened expectations- lower these a little and you'll really enjoy it here.

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom

TMuUP-xB7ooJ2jpm3qAYzQ.text: Had their special roast meal of the day. It was well prepared and tasty. The tables and such could be a bit cleaner. My table was quite sticky, and my dishware kinda iffy. Made me wonder what might be going on back in the kitchen as well.

hiOwjv8DrFtXG-FDKk71yA.text: I may not be British by birth but by gosh I appreciate some good British grub. Ergo, Canteen is one of my favourite local restaurants. A relatively upscale establishment specialising in high quality British food, and just about the best place for Sunday brunch. Period.Located smack bang in the middle of Spitalfields Market in London's East End, Canteen on a Sunday morning is a maelstrom of media types, yummy mummies and the historic area's requisite tourists. Aesthetically it is the love child of an industrial looking bachelor pad and a particularly quaint Scandinavian country abode.With its emphasis on clean, seasonal, locally sourced food and additive free meat, Canteen should easily satisfy most aware foodies' ethical imperatives while serving the kind of hearty, fail-safe food you wish your mum could master.Case in point: Canteen's breakfast and all day menu which ranges from low G.I. austere - toast and marmite, porridge - to classically decadent - bacon, fried eggs and bubble and squeak - to by-gosh-this-is-the-best-I've-ever-had Eggs Benedict.At £3.00 for an orange juice prices can be steep but quite frankly who cares when the food, and your post-meal conscience, is as clean as this.

photos.caption: Photo of Canteen - Spitalfields, London, United Kingdom

H4ONhd-mDeUnKuGy31e1PQ.text: I was very pleasantly surprised by this market eatery. I would have liked a bit more choice on the menu and some slightly lower prices but my unusual squash, fennel and barley dish was both healthy and delicious and the wine I drank was a particularly good red. The staff are helpful and are tolerant to special requests when it comes to modifications you might request to the available dishes. Probably gets very busy on certain days.

cIK2Iuxzk8UMpfmYn8HRYA.text: Canteen serves up nice British grubSleeker than you would find at a pub.With desserts so deliciousThat I'm quite suspiciousIf I went too much I'd be a chub!Seriously though, the warm apricot cobbler would probably be worth gaining a few ££s.
